Course Title: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE
Learning outcomes: Know how to develop Civil Engineering Systems (CES) within the broader social, economic, natural and built environment
use the basic concepts of continuum mechanics to define a mathematical model for a CE problem.
reduce the model to a simpler (engineering) one, explain the corresponding assumptions and classify the obtained result.
solve the reduced model/problem using the appropriate technique, interpret the behaviour and its relevance to CE practice.
Description: reduce the basic problems to simpler engineering forms
differences and similarities between the various mechanical problems

Course Title: Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers
Learning outcomes: is able to describe and formulate a research question (or alternatively, design requirements) given a set problem and select the appropriate methodology and tools
is able to present a fitting work plan to investigate a set of research questions or design requirements
is able to compose a technical document using appropriate academic language and citation with references
is able to work in a collaborative group environment effectively
is able to code according to basic coding standards (e.g., consistency, readability, conciseness, structure, etc.) and collaborate with their peers via distributed control software (e.g., git)
can perform spatial / temporal / multivariate analysis of data to extract knowledge via physics-based modelling tools, data-driven approaches, and uncertainty quantification methods

can present and communicate with peers in Civil Engineering and Geosciences, results of analyses using specific modelling, uncertainty and data approaches with appropriate metrics and visualization techniques
can design a modelling framework (from problem conceptualization to governing equation setup) for a physical/engineering process
can translate the modelling framework into discretized equations and computer code
can mathematically formulate and solve an optimization problem and discuss its properties
can assess optimization and simulation models performance using a set of indicators
can derive relevant models and complete probability and statistic calculations for faculty-wide applications
can construct relevant models for probabilistic dependence, for example using bivariate distributions or discrete Bayesian Networks
use deterministic models with probabilistic inputs to evaluate engineering questions to quantify model output uncertainty (in time and/or space)
use risk and reliability analyses concepts to describe systems, their characteristics and behaviour in time and space to support decision making under uncertainty
can identify parameters of interest, describe the functioning of common field/remote sensors used for measuring them, and explain resolution implications in space and time
is able to apply parameter estimation using observations and perform a quality assessment
can illustrate the procedure of gathering data from different sources, pre-processing it for analysis purposes, and sharing it according to FAIR principles
Explain the chemical roots of mechanical behaviour of construction materials
Categorize construction materials based on their composition, engineering properties and function
Design and predict engineering properties of construction materials based on composition and production methods
Quantify sustainability of construction materials.
Analyse, model and predict failure of construction materials
Apply fracture mechanics principles to develop materials more resistant to cracking
Select construction materials based on functional requirements, economic, environmental and ethical considerations
Design mixture of concrete, asphalt and other composite materials for application-related requirements
Description: First and Second Law of Thermodynamics
Implementation of the Prediction Methods in Real Case Situations
Engineering Materials in the Build Environment 1800-2050
the Logic of the Ashby Diagram
Materials Selection based on Optimized Performance
The Shape Factor as a parameter and Integrated Materials
Finding if a concept material is useful
Designing concept materials using the synthesizer
Curing  and Quality Control of Concrete
Reuse and Recycling in maintenance of Asphalt pavements
Special asphalt concrete types and applications.
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE

Learning outcomes: Describe the mechanical behavior (stress-strain response) of soils and rocks based on laboratory testing and data analysis
Recognize and apply the concept of constitutive modelling
Analysis and interpret laboratory tests and derive and apply mathematical formulations for engineering design
Evaluate and assess the interaction between the subsurface and geotechnical structures
Recognize, and determine the impact of the environment on the design, construction, and performance of geotechnical structures, and vice versa
Communicate the results with experts from other disciplines and other stakeholders
Assess the impact of hydro-mechanical coupling on the soil response
Description: Testing and modelling of soil behavior
mechanical behavior (stress-strain response) of soils and rocks
observed soil behavior from standard geotechnical laboratory tests
analyze and interpret the test data
model parameters needed for engineering design
soil coupled hydro-mechanical response in engineering applications
predict the behaviour of foundations and excavations
interaction between the subsurface and geotechnical structures
impact of the environment on the design
construction and performance of geotechnical structures
Ethics related to design of geotechnical structures
interaction between the subsurface and geotechnical structures
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE

Course Title: Base: Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part I
Learning outcomes: Explain the physical principles behind flow, transport, turbulence, mixing, sediment transport, surface waves and hydraulic loads.
Derive analytical/numerical models to assess typical hydraulic engineering problems based on physical principles combined with data.
Design solutions for typical hydraulic engineering problems regarding scour, siltation, contamination, sediment transport, bed stability.
Explain the characteristics of rivers, coasts, estuaries, ports and waterways in hydraulic engineering systems.
Predict and assess the behaviour of rivers, coasts, estuaries, ports and waterways in hydraulic engineering systems in response to natural and anthropogenic change taking uncertainties into account.
Identify the range of functions of rivers, coasts, estuaries, ports and waterways in hydraulic engineering systems.
Description: in-depth analysis of the hydrodynamic and transport processes
the theory and techniques to numerically solve the hydrodynamic and transport equations
the theory and tools to describe and calculate the hydraulic loads and bed protection
the dynamics of wind-generated waves in the open ocean and in coastal waters
the characteristics of a river system
the morphodynamic behaviour of these systems
underlying hydrodynamic and sediment transport processes
typical river engineering problems and methods design interventions
Fundamentals of free surface flows and transport processes
mathematical description of unsteady flow with free surface in open channels
the principles of conservation of mass and momentum
tidal basins and flood waves in rivers
transport of dissolved matter due to advection and diffusion is covered in depth
the associated two-dimensional (horizontal) and three-dimensional (vertical) flow structures
Computational modelling of flow and transport
approximation of solutions to partial differential equations (PDEs)
finite difference methods for constructing numerical solution of parabolic and hyperbolic PDEs
different numerical schemes in terms of the numerical diffusion and dispersion, along with measures to prevent wiggles
simulation of unsteady free surface flows in seas, estuaries, rivers, channels and lakes
abilities and limitations of the commonly used practices related to approximating the equations of long waves
wave components of varying frequencies and directions
irregular and directionally spread wave fields
river response to change and associated time scales
The hydraulic and morphodynamic behavior of these systems
initial, transient and equilibrium morphodynamic response

Learning outcomes: Analyse fluid- and soil-structure interaction processes, as well as structural mechanics principles, Relevant for the engineering of hydraulic and offshore structures.
Analyse scientific knowledge on fluid- and soil-structure interaction, as well as structural mechanics, that contributes to solving complex hydraulic and offshore structures.
Perform, statistically model selection and identification for fluid- and soil-structure interaction analyses.
Quantify uncertainty in models and measurements for fluid and soil-structure interaction analyses.
Evaluate uncertainty propagation for fluid-and soil-structure interaction analyses.
Description: design, construction and operation of hydraulic and offshore structures
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE

Learning outcomes: Identify and quantify the most important loads on structures, roads and railway and schematize and combine them as input for the determination of the force distributions and deformations.

Design critical steel cross sections, members and joints with optimized dimensions and reliable performance against structural and environmental requirements under the influence of single and combined bending, shear, torsion and axial loads.

Design and verify structural performance of timber members and connections subjected to single and combined bending, shear and axial loads through understanding of fundamental material properties and force flows in timber joints.

Design, analyse and optimize prestressed concrete structures, considering influence of internal stress distribution, time dependent effects, type of pre-tensioning, boundary conditions, prestress losses, cracks and reinforcement details.

Understand and apply the principles of sustainability to identify, analyse and evaluate negative effects of civil engineering structures at component and system level on natural environment and society and to use circularity strategies to reduce the environmental impact of structures, railways and roads.
Formulate the governing equations of motion of a class of one-dimensional slender structures (beams, cables, rods) and plates subjected to static and dynamic loads in- and out- of plane.
Analyse 1D slender structures subjected to static loads and dynamic loads and evaluate the structural response.
Analyse plates subjected to static and dynamic loads in- and out- of plane and evaluate the structural response.
Create mathematical models of complex structures consisting of one-dimensional elements and plates subjected to static and dynamic loads and evaluate their structural response.
Description: design and analysis of steel, timber and concrete members
Identification and quantification of loads on structures
short-term, long term, and moveable loads
the combination of different types of loads
Design of steel cross sections and members
Influence of properties of base material
verification of critical steel cross sections
Design of timber cross sections and members
verification for strength, stiffness and stability
Design and verification of timber joints and connections
prestressed concrete members exposed to forces
Application of the principles of sustainability and circularity in civil engineering structures.
Formulation of governing equations of one-dimensional and two-dimensional slender structures
combinations of one-dimensional and two-dimensional slender structures
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE

Learning outcomes: Design the traffic and transport infrastructure and networks.
Develop a traffic and transport engineering solution and analyse its performance.
Discuss, analyse and apply traffic and transport models.
Set-up, perform and report a transport engineering solution/ modelling study.
Assess the ethical and societal implications of traffic and transport engineering solutions.
Description: fundamentals of traffic and transport engineering
traffic and transport networks and infrastructure

Course Title: Measuring and Modelling Construction Material Behaviour
Learning outcomes: Set up a computational model for simulation of the behaviour of materials
Perform linear and nonlinear finite element analysis for mechanical and transport problems
Calibrate and validate computational models with experimental observations
Set up a testing plan for characterisation of materials to define input parameters for structural analysis
Analyse experimental measurements to characterise the performance of construction materials
Advise structural engineers on characterisation and modelling strategies for describing material behaviour
Quantify uncertainty in models and measurements
Description: multi- scale and multi-physics modelling techniques
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE
Base: Fundamentals of Construction Materials

Learning outcomes: Define durability concepts of construction materials, describe material properties and their effect on durability.
List and explain physical, chemical and biological degradation mechanisms of construction materials.
Perform service life design of structures based on material properties.
Set-up repair and maintenance strategies for degraded structures
Analyse and predict the influence of eigenstresses in materials on the behaviour of structural elements and components
Explain how environmental effects and different gradients on material level and structural level impose deformations and stresses
Formulate constitutive models to describe the linear/nonlinear response of materials and implement them in FEM codes
Select and apply constitutive models for various physicochemical material behaviours.
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE
Base: Fundamentals of Construction Materials

Course Title: Design and Engineering of Construction Materials
Learning outcomes: Advise on the use of construction materials and production processes for reliable and sustainable structural design
Design potential routes for recycling and reusing of EoL (End-of-Life) construction materials
Analyse the environmental impact of construction materials in their complete life cycle
Develop strategies for sustainable use of materials in construction
Facilitate the use of new, high performance and sustainable materials (e.g. UHPFRC, SHCC, geopolymer, bio-based materials, epoxy-modified bitumen) in structural engineering
Evaluate current trends in the development of smart and sustainable construction materials
Explain the opportunities and challenges of additive manufacturing technologies (such as 3D printing) in construction
Analyse the short- and long-term behaviour of polymer and bio-based composite materials
Description: design, performance and engineering of smart materials
bio-based and polymer-based composite and hybrid materials.
Pre-requisites: Base: Fundamentals of Construction Materials

Learning outcomes: Acquire conceptual (hydro)geological knowledge on project site;
Integrate (hydro-)geological information and knowledge into ground models and estimate resulting uncertainty for a variety of geotechnical applications
Formulate, explain and solve the (equations of the) finite element method in the context of numerical modelling of geotechnical applications;
Design and execute numerical simulations for geotechnical applications;
Critically evaluate the results and the limitations of model solutions for geological and geotechnical problems, considering data and model uncertainty;

Communicate results of geo-engineering investigation and numerical simulations to stakeholders in terms of geo-risks and opportunities, in the context of a responsible use of the subsurface for multi-purposes.
Description: conceptual ground and ground water flow modelling
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE
Base: Geotechnical Engineering
Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers

Learning outcomes: describe the nature, impact and characterisation of soil spatial variability.
explain the relationship between soil spatial variability and geotechnical design and risk assessment.
evaluate advantages and shortcomings of different alternative choices for the design of infrastructure.
evaluate the design and construction methods for different types of infrastructure.
identify suitable site investigation techniques and critically analyse the results of a site investigation survey.
analyse geotechnical problems based on physical and numerical modelling techniques.
Description: design, monitoring and assessment of geotechnical structures
the evaluation of risk and uncertainty in geotechnical engineering
the interaction between soil layers and the geotechnical structure
the impact of geotechnical structures on other structures in an urban environment
analysis of conventional and innovative geotechnical monitoring
the evaluation of data from site investigation
Risk and variability in geotechnical engineering
Pre-requisites: Base: Geotechnical Engineering
Geotechnical Engineering

Learning outcomes: analyse the role of advanced, time-dependent features of soils' hydro-mechanical behaviour
identify and integrate testing and constitutive modelling strategies for soils subjected to environmental and man-induced perturbations
select and perform advanced analyses of geotechnical problems based on most appropriate physical/numerical modelling techniques
critically reflect on benefits and limitations of advanced physical and numerical modelling strategies in geotechnical engineering
effectively report in writing the outcome of advanced experimental and computational analyses in relation to geotechnical engineering applications
Description: overview and issues with deltaic soils
Advanced numerical modelling of large deformations
engineering and design aspects of geotechnical projects
Start numerical modelling of case study
Elaboration of case study and results
Direct simple shear and ring shear test
From linear to non-linear cyclic/dynamic soil behaviour
Pre-requisites: Base: Geotechnical Engineering
Geotechnical Engineering

Learning outcomes: describe testing and constitutive modelling strategies for soils subjected to environmental and man-induced perturbations.
explain the role of advanced, time-related features of soils' hydro-mechanical behaviour.
evaluate advantages and shortcomings of different alternative choices for the design of infrastructure.
evaluate the design and construction methods for different types of infrastructure.
compare the various methods for site investigation.
analyse geotechnical problems based on physical and numerical modelling techniques
Description: design, monitoring and assessment of geotechnical structures
the interaction between soil layers and the geotechnical structure
impact of geotechnical structures on other structures in an urban environment
evaluation of data from site investigation
Pre-requisites: Base: Geotechnical Engineering
Geotechnical Engineering

Course Title: Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part II
Learning outcomes: Explain the physical principles behind flow, transport, turbulence, mixing, sediment transport, surface waves and hydraulic loads.
Derive analytical/numerical models to assess typical hydraulic engineering problems based on physical principles combined with data.
Design solutions for typical hydraulic engineering problems regarding scour, siltation, contamination, sediment transport, bed stability.
Explain the characteristics of rivers, coasts, estuaries, ports and waterways in hydraulic engineering systems.
Predict and assess the behaviour of rivers, coasts, estuaries, ports and waterways in hydraulic engineering systems in response to natural and anthropogenic change taking uncertainties into account.
Description: the characteristics of a range of coastal systems
the morphodynamic behaviour of these systems
Introduction to Port and Waterway Systems
the importance of port and waterway systems in supporting waterborne supply chains at different scales
performance optimization from an infrastructure perspective
analyzing the performance of systems of ports/terminals and waterways
Pre-requisites: Base: Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part I
Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers
Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE

Learning outcomes: Analyse and assess in depth the complex behaviour of coastal and estuarine systems (deltas, estuaries, beaches and dunes, tidal plains, barrier and lagoon coasts) including the response of these systems to human interventions
Apply models to predict the behaviour of coastal and estuarine systems and assess the impact of coastal engineering interventions
Apply the theories of wave loads on different types of slope protection
In collaboration propose and design coastal engineering interventions for purposes such as protection against flooding and erosion and construction in water
Account for uncertainties in relation to monitoring, modelling and data analysis for research and design
Clearly present and report design and modelling results
Description: the assessment of the impact of these interventions, their technical design
Ethical issues, the role of the engineer
conflicting perspectives of various vocal and non-vocal stakeholders.
Advanced Coastal and Estuarine Systems treats, in-depth, coastal and estuarine processes and system behaviour
waves, tides, currents, coarse and fine sediment transport, morphodynamic change
response to interventions, storm surge barriers, groynes, dredging and nourishments
coastal systems, deltas, estuaries, beaches and dunes, tidal plains, barrier, lagoon coasts
their complex interplay in the built and natural environment
Shore protection & Breakwaters treats the mechanisms of (in)stability of protection layers under wave loads
practical implementation of these protection, construction, environment, uncertainty, maintenance
Pre-requisites: Base: Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part I
Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part II

Learning outcomes: understand and apply scientific knowledge that contributes to solving river system-related problems in an ethically sound manner
analyse and assess the behaviour of river systems and catchment, and assess and predict the system response to interventions, while taking into account neighbouring/adjacent systems
analyze the problem
formulate functional requirements and constraints
formulate alternative solutions (including autonomous development)

design human interventions in the river or catchment environment for purposes such as flood protection, nature development or restoration, navigation, freshwater supply, ecology, port operability, water quality, and construction in water
account for societal, environmental, and economic aspects, and uncertainties in research and design, at various scales

account for the complexities of multidisciplinary environments and the range of stakeholders: (inter)national river management authorities, nature organisations, NGOs, dredging companies, navigation stakeholders, other governments.
Description: response to anthropogenic or natural change
Schematization and Modelling of River Problems
assess the problem using appropriate tools
balance between economy, safety, and sustainability
Pre-requisites: Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers
Base: Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part I
Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part II

Course Title: Advanced Design of Ports and Waterways, Systems and Interventions
Learning outcomes: Analyse logistic and operational processes in ports and waterways systems and discuss the capacity controlling parameters
Design port/terminal and waterway infrastructure to pre-defined objectives covering economic, societal and environmental aspects

Design interventions in ports and waterways systems, model interactions ranging from simple to complex, between physical processes and port and waterways systems, and apply simulations for the evaluation of performance
Design hard and soft infrastructure interventions to improve port, terminal, and waterway performance including quantifying trade-offs and discussing these trade-offs with peers
Demonstrate the learning over intervention design and performance evaluation in real-life case studies
Apply data science techniques and concepts for a quantitative analysis of processes in port and waterway systems in various design exercises.
Description: Advanced dimensioning of waterways and waterway elements
Simulation for ports and waterways (planning and trade-offs)
Data science for ports and waterways
Pre-requisites: Hydraulic Engineering Fundamentals and Environments Part II

Learning outcomes: Generate sound preliminary designs for hydraulic structures based on current natural and societal needs, accounting for its interaction with the environment its life-cycle aspects, using available scientific knowledge.
Analyse principles of ultimate resistance and fatigue relevant for the design of hydraulic structures, using available scientific knowledge
Perform statistically model selection and identification for the analysis and verification of the structural health of hydraulic structures.
Effectively collaborate and communicate with the aim to generate and optimize the design of hydraulic structures.
Critically reflect on the design and reliability of hydraulic structures and its structural components.
Translate current natural and societal needs into possible technical designs of offshore structures by accounting for relevant moral values, norms and principles.
Description: analyse a problem to formulate a design objective
methods and values of design parameters
Pre-requisites: Base: Hydraulic and Offshore Structures

Learning outcomes: Generate sound preliminary designs for offshore structures, accounting for its interaction with the environment and its life-cycle aspects, using available scientific knowledge.
Analyse principles of ultimate resistance and fatigue relevant for the design of offshore structures, using available scientific knowledge.
Perform, statistically sound and context-based, model selection and identification for the analysis and verification of the structural health of offshore structures.
Effectively collaborate and communicate with the aim to generate and optimize offshore structures designs.
Critically reflect on the design and reliability of offshore structures and its structural components.
Translate current natural and societal needs into possible technical designs of offshore structures by accounting for relevant moral values, norms and principles.
Description: offshore, geotechnical, structural and reliability aspects
the assembly of the structural configuration
the determination and assessment of the permanent, variable and environmental loads on the structure
the design and analysis of its foundation
the static and dynamic structural analysis of the structure based on ultimate strength and fatigue principles
Pre-requisites: Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers

Learning outcomes: Create offshore renewable solutions based on future natural and societal needs, using available scientific knowledge
Evaluate offshore renewable structures in interaction with the surrounding environment, using available scientific knowledge
Convey quantified uncertain outcomes corresponding the design of hydraulic and offshore structures
Propose new ways for dealing with ethical issues within the field of hydraulic and offshore structures from the perspective of different relevant moral frameworks

Conduct a solution-oriented debate with stakeholders about ethical issues within the field of hydraulic and offshore structures, while acknowledging real-world constraints in terms of technological possibilities, governance and institutional options
Description: offshore wind and ocean energy farms

Evaluate dams, dikes and breakwaters in interaction with the surrounding environment, using available scientific knowledge
Convey quantified uncertain outcomes corresponding to the design of dams, dikes and breakwaters
Consider ways of dealing with ethical issues within the field of dams, dikes and breakwaters from the perspective of different relevant moral frameworks

Conduct a solution-oriented debate with stakeholders about ethical issues within the field of dams, dikes and breakwaters, while acknowledging real-world constraints in terms of technological possibilities, governance and institutional options

structures to protect beds, banks and shorelines

Propose new ways for dealing with ethical issues within the field of hydraulic and offshore structures from the perspective of different relevant moral frameworks

Conduct a solution-oriented debate with stakeholders about ethical issues within the field of hydraulic and offshore structures, while acknowledging real-world constraints in terms of technological possibilities, governance and institutional options

Offshore Structures

Learning outcomes: Analyse the stability of structures subjected to both static and dynamics loads.
Explain the theoretical background of finite element formulations for structural analysis.
Perform finite element analysis to analyse the force distribution, stability and dynamic response of frame structures.
Analyse and interpret vibration measurements to identify modal parameters, including their associated uncertainty.
Design a measurement set-up for vibration analysis, with the purpose of quantifying modelling and measurement uncertainties.
Pre-requisites: Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers

Learning outcomes: Explain the principles to design prefabricated and structural (composite) components in a circular manner for buildings and infrastructure by using conventional and novel civil engineering materials

Apply the advanced design aspects in structural engineering, focusing on stability problems, understanding and designing composite members, connections, detailing, external prestressing and prefabricated members with conventional construction materials (timber, steel, concrete).

Design, analyse and optimize composite structural members, e.g. steel-concrete, timber-concrete, timber-steel beams, decks and columns, with respect to short and long term loads and environmental conditions.
illustrate the influence of connections and detailing aspects in prefabricated and composite structures and apply this in the design and verification
Identify the innovative, high performance and sustainable civil engineering materials and simulate their behaviour.
Discuss limitations and advantages of applying novel materials, advanced manufacturing and innovative systems in design of structural members and optimize design accordingly
Discover and justify the possibilities of applying innovative materials in real engineering problems to improve the design and behaviour of the structure or the road and railway system.
Description: possibilities and limitations of both conventional and innovative construction materials
Design verification of steel members (beam-columns) exposed to interaction, axial force and transversal load
prerequisites and consequences of full and partial composite action
Prefabricated elements for building and infrastructure
prestressed concrete sleepers, timber sleepers, composite sleepers
Introduce new types of cementitious materials ((SHCC), UHPFRC, Geopolymer concrete, auxetic, phase change, self-sensing, self-healing, 3d printed, recycled)
Adaptive design for easy dismantling and reusing structural materials
HIGH PERFORMANCE STEEL AND COMPOSITE STRUCTURES
High strength steel Composite materials and members
Emerging materials to enhance performance and functionality of pavement
Pre-requisites: Base: Structural Engineering

Course Title: Design of Civil Structures and Infrastructures
Learning outcomes: Integrate steps of conceptual and preliminary design phases of (infra)structures to design a (infra)structure from scratch taking into account the demand of the client and the society, the interaction between the structure and its environment and the need of lifetime maintenance, including design for circularity, while quantifying uncertainties in the brief, the boundary conditions, the loads, the design, and the construction phase

Select optimal structural systems (traditional or innovative) for specific design task of buildings and bridges and combination of construction materials steel, timber and concrete, to be able to realize which options can be chosen for the structural system, taken into account the uncertainty in the end-use, lifespan and degradation mechanisms.

Explain how to analyse the interfaces and interaction of track infrastructure and train and their effects on the railway system and the various influencing structural pavement design parameters on different supporting structures

Explain principles of parametric geometry design and the uncertainty in tolerances that have to be taken into account, and apply these principles with appropriate software tools cooperatively in a design team.
Examine transfer of forces in different structural systems and with different structural materials starting from the applied load down to the foundation.
Design the structural systems consisting of structural members and joints with appropriate dimensions and materials in a realistic design context
Learn to work in a design team and to make and visualize and present a functional design of a site including buildings, bridges, rails, and roads
Develop general design of a building, bridge, railways and road structural system to a detailed design level through cooperation within a design team.
Description: design of buildings, bridges, rail track and roads/pavements
ethical aspects of design of engineering structures
Pre-requisites: Base: Structural Engineering
Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers

Learning outcomes: Analyze the mechanical response of structures where that is complicated by the presence of geometric and material nonlinearity
Calculate the ultimate load of plates and frames accounting for plasticity
Explore the limits of analytical tools for evaluation of elastic stress and strain
Formulate, implement and test constitutive laws for detailed numerical analysis of the response of structures
Perform nonlinear finite element analysis for structural design verification

Select an appropriate mechanical model that idealizes the physical problem of analysis of a structure (boundary conditions, loading, dimension reduction, geometric order of approximation, material model)
Build an appropriate finite element model that discretizes the selected mechanical model
Carry out nonlinear finite element analysis for a range of different applications (steel/concrete structures, seismic response of buildings)
Interpret finite element solution results to solve engineering problems
Create a technical report of a performed finite element analysis

Select an appropriate constitutive model to account for physical phenomena of time-dependent behavior, direction dependent behavior, permanent deformations and failure in the analysis of material response
Derive and apply the stiffness relations for orthotropic elasticity and classical laminate theory
Understand and apply the concepts of large deformation mechanics
Explain the concepts of thermodynamics and apply it to large deformation elasto-thermal material modelling
Explain and apply concepts of elasto-plasticity, visco-elasticity, viscoplasticity in small and large deformation formulations
Formulate constitutive models to describe the nonlinear response of materials
Implement constitutive models as user material in finite element code
Verify consistency of a user material implementation with its intended behavior

Reproduce the main steps in the derivation of analytical elaticity solutions, for example the point load on a half space, point load on a half disk, stresses around a spherical cavity in a continuum, stresses around a circular opening in a plate, moments in circular plates, stresses in curved beams, the differential equations for torsion
Demonstrate understanding of the physical meaning of these analytical solutions
Argue about the usefulness and limitations of these solutions and of elasticity theory in general
Explain the upperbound and lowerbound theorems for plastic collapse
Calculate, by hand, the ultimate load of elastic/plastic frames with or without accounting for moment-normal force interaction
Calculate, by hand, the ultimate load of elastic/plastic plates
Description: behaviour of materials, structures and structural elements
Introduction to the use of the finite element method
Nonlinear finite element analysis of steel structures
Nonlinear finite element analysis of structures made of a quasi-brittle material
Application of the finite element method to solve engineering problems
Fracture models and continuum damage mechanics
Pre-requisites: Base: Structural Engineering
Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers

Learning outcomes: Describe conceptually the earthquakes, wind, wave and vehicle loads on structures
Formulate and interpret the physical foundations of mathematical models for the dynamics of structures under earthquakes, wind, wave and vehicle loads
Describe, model and analyse the earthquakes, waves, wind, and rail and road irregularities as random signals
Understand and apply analytical methods of mathematical analysis of the dynamic response of structures to earthquakes, wind, waves and moving loads
Describe and explain the main mechanisms of vibration excitation of structures by moving loads
Analyse the dynamic response of structures in earthquake-prone regions and use it in design considerations
Design structures for renewable energy generation based on their response to wind and waves
Compute and evaluate the dynamic response of bridges to moving loads and use it in design considerations
Compute and evaluate the dynamic response of rigid and flexible pavements at the tirepavement interface and use it in design considerations
Compute and evaluate the dynamic behaviour of a railway track and its environment under train loading and use it in design considerations
Explain basic seismological concept
Analyse recorded ground motions and distinguish local site effects
Formulate the equations of motion of NDOF systems subjected to ground excitation and critically assess their correctness
Apply different methods of seismic analysis in structures (linear and non-linear response) and analyse the results
Consider soil-structure interaction and fluid-structure interaction in seismic analysis of structures
Analyse and design structures in earthquake-prone regions using code provisions
Describe wind and waves stochastically
Formulate and interpret the physical foundations of mathematical models for the structural wind and wave loads on structures
Formulate and evaluate the equations of motion of NDOF systems subjected to wind and wave excitations
Define wind and wave interactions with basic structural concepts
Analyse the dynamic response of simple structures to wind and wave excitations
Describe the phenomena of galloping, flutter and vortex-induced vibrations
Design and analyse the dynamic response of structures for renewable energy generation from wind and waves
Describe and formulate mathematical models for the structural elements and structures in interaction with moving loads
Describe and explain the major types of structural and environmental responses to moving loads
Derive and analyse the response of 1D structures and 3D layered continua to moving loads
Design a concept bridge model under moving loads and evaluate its dynamic response
Design rigid and flexible pavements under moving loads and evaluate their dynamic responses and of their environment, taking into account the stochastic nature of the loading
Compute and evaluate the dynamic behaviour of a railway track under train loading and design environmentally friendly tracks, taking into account the stochastic nature of the loading
Describe the degradation mechanisms of road
Interpreted simplified theoretical models with limit state theorems of the theory of plasticity
Design and assess various structural types using limit analyses, the types of structures include beam, wall, slabs, and joints.
Point out the fracture process of concrete and its difference between linear elastic fracture mechanics.
Outline the influence of the local fracture process of concrete on the global structural behaviour in terms of fatigue behaviour, shear and punching shear behaviour, etc.
Outline the fundamentals of concrete materials
Explain the mechanisms and the chemical process relate to the strength development and the resultant mechanical properties
Control volume change during the hardening process
Design concrete mixture and advise corresponding execution methodology.
Create appropriate finite element models for reinforced concrete structures or elements
Interpret nonlinear finite element analysis results
Explain how to account for uncertainties when using finite element analysis
Compile adequate finite element analysis reports.

Explain the behaviour of concrete structures under temperature effects in the early stage of hardening and hardened concrete, including (technological and structural) measures to influence this behaviour.
DIscuss the difference between structural response under external loads and imposed deformations, and design concrete structures subjected to imposed deformations.
Design and execution of storage systems and reservoirs in reinforced and prestressed concrete, focusing on tightness criteria.
Design of concrete protective structures under extreme loads, e.g. impact, blast, fire, cryogenic loads.
Design concrete structures for cyclic loading with various amplitude and duration such as seismic loading and fatigue loading
Outline the main environmental loads and possible deteriorations of concrete structures.
Outline the considerations of designing a concrete bridge in the Netherlands.

Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages between different construction methods (cast in situ) and able to explain the relationship between the construction method and the alignment of the reinforcement and/or prestressing cables.
Apply the different traffic load models specified in the Eurocode.
Apply the methods of load distribution.
Evaluate the different alternatives and analyse and calculate roughly the main dimensions of the bridge.
Choose the different types of bearings and expansion joints properly.
Design concrete structures and members using plasticity theory and fracture mechanics for concrete.
Explain and design cement-based building materials and the advanced concrete mixture design methodology, further apply to design, control, and execute durable and sustainable concrete in practice.
Create, carry out, interpret, and document nonlinear finite element analysis of reinforced concrete structures or elements.
Model the behaviour of concrete members and structures subject to various environmental and anthropogenic loads, and to create appropriate design accordingly.
Design and assess precast and cast-in-situ concrete bridges and bridge elements considering the construction methods and the loading conditions.
Create, carry out, interpret and document linear and nonlinear finite element analysis of steel members and connections/joints.
Improve design models for resistance of structural members and joints based on quantification and understanding of scattering of material and structural properties (e.g. partial factors).
Explain the concept of the Monte Carlo method and perform Monte Carlo simulations using Excel and Python programming.
Explain the fatigue initiation and crack propagation process and mechanism and determine the main factors influencing the fatigue strength of materials, connections, and structures.
Explain the basics of the fatigue behaviour of critical details (welded connections, bolted connections, tubular joints) and the theoretical background of prediction methods.
Design steel structures exposed to cyclic loading (fatigue strength) and explain design concepts in the presence of structural damage based on the lifetime prediction methodologies.
Design ductile, damage tolerant and reusable moment resisting and simple joints in steel structures for their beam-to-column and column to base-plate connections.
Apply the theoretical background to create engineering models for the design verifications of the structural connections/joints exposed to monotonic, cyclic and impact loading.
Understand the design requirements and principles of designing diverse fixed or movable highway, railway and pedestrian bridges.
Design durable, sustainable and cost-efficient bridges by integrating global structural, cross-section and deck systems.
Analyse structural behaviour of steel and steel-concrete bridges in response to construction phases, traffic and environmental loads.
Analyse ultimate, serviceability and fatigue limit states of new and existing bridges.
Optimise construction time and costs by combining diverse production and execution methods.
Create strengthening solutions for existing bridges.
Calculate the loads applied in the supporting structure of wind turbine towers and evaluate their structural performance.

Validate the design of the tubular and multi-membered towers/jackets and their connections by using calculations according to structural design codes, guidelines and linear and non-linear FE models, including imperfections.
Design lightweight rolled, welded, cold-formed, stiffened and unstiffened cross-sectional steel members of plated and cylindrical steel structures.

analyse the effects of local buckling, imperfections and post-buckling behaviour in thin-walled plated and cylindrical structural members and apply engineering methods to perform the design verification.
Design and analyse steel frames by considering members' imperfections and limit state provisions of design codes.
Choose optimal combinations of FRP materials and production processes for a specific application in infrastructure and set of loading and environment conditions.
Design FRP structures by considering the structure's specific material behaviour and mechanical and functional requirements.

Analyse the mechanical performance and failure modes of FRP structures and joints on the level of plies, laminates and structural components using Classical Laminate Theory, progressive failure analysis and Finite Element models.
Verify designs of FRP structural members and joints by using calculations according to structural design codes.
Description: decommission of steel and composite structures
Modelling of Steel and Composite structures
Elastic, plastic and damage material modelling of steel and FRP
Modelling of local and global elastic buckling
Evaluation of design values for resistance of various failure modes of steel members
Design verification of steel connections and joints
resistance of bolts, welds, net cross-section in tension and shear
Shear and axially loaded joints Simple connections
Beam to column moment resistant joints
Design of steel structures against fatigue failure
Local prediction models (Hot spot stress approach, SCF, effective notch stress) by FE analysis on examples of hollow section joints, OSD
Crack initiation and propagation by analytical models and FEA
Design verifications of steel bridge elements
Execution and details of steel bridges
Renovation and maintenance of steel bridges
Hollow section steel joints in jacket structures
Monopile supporting structures for wind turbines and connections
Stability and resistance of complex columns and frames
Stability of welded and rolled steel members
FRP Composite Structures Design of FRP structures FRP material behaviour
Analysis and verification of FRP structural members Analysis and verification of FRP joints and details
Pre-requisites: Base: Structural Engineering
Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers
Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE

Learning outcomes: recognise and discuss architectural styles and construction methods of the 19th, 20th and 21st century;

distinguish faade typologies and use those in design, while correctly applying the laws of building physics in the design evaluation to meet relevant criteria for climate, energy-efficiency and durability, taking into account stochastic material properties, climate data and user behaviour;

discuss the relationship and integration between design of load bearing structure, faade structure and other relevant parts/aspects of the building, such as services, vertical transport, plumbing, climate, ducts;

analyse whether reuse of existing structures or structural components in a project is economically and technically feasible and, where it is, reuse such existing building structures in the design of the newly developed building, correctly assessing the reliability of the existing structure or components based on measurements or probabilistic reasoning;
correctly identify functional, structural and construction requirements and loads for low-rise and multi-storey buildings with different targeted functions;

explain and apply, in the context of a design, the most important typologies and stability systems of low-rise and multi-storey buildings, using different construction materials, and being able to model and simulate the behaviour of such systems both with self-written code and existing FEM software;

develop, analyse and evaluate various reliable solutions for building foundations and deep basements in close cooperation with a geoengineer, considering the close interaction between structure and foundation, recognising and limiting risks of uncertain underground soil conditions, surveying and foundation methods;

explain how a building design can be constructed in an economic, safe and practical manner, acknowledging what the consequences and risks of construction methods are for the design and vice versa, and acting as a structural engineer with a professional, responsible and ethical attitude;
Design spatial structures (such as domes, (grid)shells, inflatables and membrane structures, space frames, cable systems and tensegrity structures), analyse and explain their 3D structural action;
Use advanced design tools, numerical analysis tools, and physical models or measurements to analyse and visualise 3D structural behaviour, and develop such models in self-written code.
Description: building physics (heat transport, acoustics, wind flow)
building services (heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, vertical transport, water)
advanced knowledge on the flow of forces in building structures
various typologies of buildings according to their function
use and reuse of various building materials
interaction with the subsoil via the foundation
Impact on surroundings and urban context
economy and material efficiency (zero-waste) on the construction site
Pre-requisites: Base: Structural Engineering
Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers
Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE

Learning outcomes: Analyse the design-construction-service cycle of transportation infrastructures
Evaluate state-of-the-art construction processes and techniques for transportation infrastructures
Evaluate transportation infrastructures modelling and design solutions, considering the effects of the inherent dynamics, operational conditions, and relevant sources of uncertainties
Propose physics-based and data-based monitoring and maintenance solutions for transportation infrastructures
Create innovative and ethical solutions and compare results with the state-of-the-art knowledge in real-life challenges from selected case studies from the industry

Practice and further develop effective communication skills (both written and oral) to ethically share results and opinions with peers, engineers, academics, and stakeholders from the transportation infrastructure industry
Provide constructive feedback, resolve possible conflicts in diverse teams, and ethically tackle critical transportation infrastructure challenges
Analyse and evaluate methods for the construction process of transportation infrastructures
Evaluate design aspects and procedures for transportation infrastructures
Explain the capabilities of different design methods and solutions under different parameters, variations, and uncertainties in properties and loading patterns
Select and apply design methods, and propose improvements in the construction and design of transportation infrastructures by tackling real-life case studies from the transportation industry
Evaluate current practices of maintenance in the transportation infrastructure industry
Ethically and effectively discuss and analyze results with main stakeholders.
Evaluate the most important dynamics and operational conditions of existing transportation infrastructures
Explain degradation mechanisms that can affect transportation infrastructures during their whole life cycle
Assess the performance over time of transportation infrastructures, considering both dynamics and the influence of degradation mechanism
Select and apply methodologies to estimate the remaining lifetime of existing transportation infrastructures
Discuss and present results to different stakeholders effectively and ethically.
Implement state-of-the-art monitoring solutions for transportation infrastructures
Evaluate current practices of maintenance in the transportation infrastructure industry
Design intelligent condition-based maintenance strategies including both physics and data-based characteristics of transportation infrastructures
Assess the performance of transportation infrastructures over their whole life-cycle, including sustainability aspects
Effectively and ethically present results and discuss their advantages and disadvantages to different stakeholders.
Description: static, moving, and crowd sensing technologies
Pre-requisites: Interdisciplinary Mechanics and Design for CE
Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers
Base: Structural Engineering

Course Title: Methods in Traffic and Transport Engineering
Learning outcomes: Formulate research questions and hypotheses in relation to transport infrastructure, network, operations and behaviour
Design and conduct experiments in the realm of transport infrastructure, network, operations and behaviour
Analyze and interpret empirical and simulation data about transport infrastructure, network, operations and behaviour
Formulate a mathematical optimisation model addressing problems related to transport infrastructure, network, operations and behaviour
Solve optimisation problems using solvers and tailored designed efficient algorithms also considering stochasticity in the inputs.
Develop and implement simulation model functionalities for representing transport infrastructure, network, operations and behaviour

Develop suitable data-driven modelling approaches for verification, calibration and validation of models, input and parameters in the context of transport infrastructure, network, operations and behaviour
Compare models' properties and performance for analyzing transport infrastructure, network, operations and behaviour
Apply techniques for risk and uncertainty analysis for transport data and models
Description: empirical analysis for transport and traffic engineering
simulation and uncertainty in transport engineering.
Pre-requisites: Modelling, Uncertainty and Data for Engineers
Base: Traffic and Transport Engineering

Learning outcomes: To create integrated solutions for transport networks for various modes, services and user classes to resolve performance challenges.
To evaluate the performance impact of current and (potential) future networks for users and society in different dimensions.
To assess the suitability of standard methods for real-world transport network design problems.
To analyse the current and the expected future performance of transport systems, services and networks and their tuning with land use.
To apply different standard methods for the design of transport networks.
To operationalise performance indicators for transport networks including links with norms and methods of measurement.
To explain which theoretical approaches, optimisation and calculation methods and models are needed for performance estimation, assessment and design steps.
To explain dynamic complexity between transport networks, and land use and other systems (system of systems).
To define road and freight transport networks in the societal, sustainability, perspective and define the main related design problems.
To define road and freight transport networks in their technical and user characteristics, and define the main related design problems.
Description: functioning of transport networks for passenger and freight transport
the interaction with economical and spatial development
route assignment for passenger and freight transport
the impact on performance indicators for users and the society
Optimisation and assessment of the design

Learning outcomes: Analyse, assess, model, predict, and manage road infrastructure systems
Design and evaluate intelligent vehicle systems to increase traffic safety, efficiency and sustainability
Participate, contribute and effectively communicate in debates and professional projects involving international, multicultural and interdisciplinary teams.
Acquire new knowledge and skills to continue operating effectively.
Description: Intelligent vehicles for safe and efficient traffic
Urban and Motorway Traffic Flow Modelling and Control

Learning outcomes: Analyse key dependencies among design variables, parameters, and criteria concerning organisation, service, infrastructure, operations and demand of road- and rail-bound public transport.
Apply and evaluate strategic, tactical, and operational design methods to align public transport/railway services with emerging societal and environmental needs.
Analyse processes and develop models for capturing interactions among system components including functional relations with other transport systems, society, and environment.
Design and evaluate intervention plans to build/upgrade, manage and operate public transport and railways in line with customer and stakeholders' requirements.
Define and apply methods to predict and assess service performances of public transport/railway systems and the impacts on other systems, society, and the environment.

Demonstrate team cooperation, communication, and work management capabilities in three group projects and formative assignments, to support the development of lifelong skills required in the professional world.
Description: behavioural and network modelling of PT
design and analysis of PT systems
railway automation and coordination in the railway value chain
planning, management and control of road- and rail-bound public transport operations

Learning outcomes: Identify key components for road and railway infrastructure design.
Explain fundamental -mechanics and -dynamics of road and railway infrastructures tailored for traffic operation.

Assess the road and railway infrastructure condition and predict their performances in terms of reliability, availability, maintainability, safety, sustainability, resilience, serviceability, and robustness for smooth traffic management.
Design road and railway infrastructure based on traffic operation demands.
Improve the sustainability and reliability of the road and railway infrastructure during the design-construction-operation cycle.
Assess the effectiveness of state-of-the-art monitoring solutions and the relation between usage, condition and maintenance strategies for road and railway infrastructure.
Evaluate innovative and ethical solutions to current and future challenges of road and railway infrastructure asset management.
Propose innovative and ethical solutions to actual challenges of the road and railway infrastructure industries, based on operational traffic demands.
Effectively and ethically report and communicate results with stakeholders from the industry.
Description: design of road and railway infrastructures
robustness and resilience under climate change conditions
the use of new and more sustainable materials and design techniques
AI-based monitoring and maintenance methods for road and railway infrastructure
the effect of new technologies on design and maintenance of road/railway infrastructure
ethically assess the road/railway infrastructure condition
its effect on traffic, capacity, and performance over time.

Course Title: Upscaling Techniques in Construction Materials Design and Engineering
Advanced modelling of turbulent flows and transport
Contact and Interface Mechanics for Engineering Structures
Loading and Life Time Prediction of Transportation Infrastructure
Advanced Data Science for Traffic and Transportation
Data Science and Artificial Intelligence for Engineers
Noise and Vibration: generation, propagation and effect on humans and environment
Advanced Topics in Probability and Statistics in Engineering
Resilient Deltas under Climate Change; Delta Technology
Monitoring of Structural Health and Geohazards
